ProjectOverview.title: JavaScript Ping Pong Game
ProjectOverview.description: A browser‑based, real‑time ping pong (table tennis) game built with HTML5 Canvas and vanilla JavaScript. The game supports both single‑player (against AI) and two‑player (local) modes, includes physics, scoring, and a simple UI. It is designed to be lightweight, responsive, and easily extensible.
deliverables: Fully functional web page with game canvas
Responsive UI for mobile and desktop

UserStories.description: As a player, I want to control a paddle with my mouse or touch so that I can hit the ball.
acceptanceCriteria: Paddle follows cursor or touch position horizontally.
Movement is limited to the player's half of the court.

UserStories.description: As a player, I want to play against an AI opponent so that I can practice without a second player.
acceptanceCriteria: AI paddle moves automatically with a realistic reaction time.
Difficulty levels (Easy, Medium, Hard) adjust AI speed and anticipation.

UserStories.description: As a player, I want to play with a friend on the same device so that we can compete locally.
acceptanceCriteria: Two paddles controlled by separate input methods (mouse or keyboard).
Each paddle is color‑coded and labeled.

UserStories.description: As a player, I want to see my score so that I know who is winning.
acceptanceCriteria: Current score is displayed prominently above the game area.
Score updates instantly after a point is scored.

UserStories.description: As a player, I want to start, pause, and reset the game so that I can control the flow.
acceptanceCriteria: Start button initiates a new game.
Pause button freezes ball and paddle movement.
Reset button clears score and returns to initial state.

UserStories.description: As a player, I want the game to be responsive so that it works on both desktop and mobile.
acceptanceCriteria: Canvas resizes to fit screen while maintaining aspect ratio.
Touch controls work on mobile devices.

UserStories.description: As a developer, I want the code to be modular and testable so that I can maintain and extend it.
acceptanceCriteria: Game logic is separated into modules (Game, Paddle, Ball, AI, UI).
Unit tests cover core physics and scoring logic.

FunctionalRequirements.description: Render game elements (paddles, ball, net, scoreboard) on an HTML5 canvas.
Implement ball physics: velocity, angle of deflection based on paddle contact point.
Detect collisions between ball and paddles, walls, and net.
Update scores when the ball passes a paddle.
Provide three difficulty settings for AI: Easy (slow, predictable), Medium (moderate speed), Hard (fast, anticipatory).
Allow the user to select game mode: Single‑player or Two‑player.
Implement start, pause, and reset controls via buttons and keyboard shortcuts.
Persist high score in localStorage to display a leaderboard.
Provide visual feedback: ball flashes when speed increases, paddle changes color when hit.
Implement responsive design: canvas resizes with window, controls adapt to touch.

NonFunctionalRequirements.description: Performance: Frame rate of at least 60 FPS on modern browsers.
Reliability: Game should recover gracefully from errors (e.g., lost animation frame).
Usability: Controls should be intuitive with minimal learning curve.
Accessibility: Keyboard navigation support and ARIA labels for controls.
Security: No external dependencies that could introduce vulnerabilities.
Maintainability: Codebase follows ES6 module conventions, with clear documentation.

BusinessRules.rule: A point is awarded to a player when the ball passes beyond the opponent's paddle (i.e., crosses the left or right boundary).
The game ends when a player reaches 11 points, unless 'best of' is specified in settings.
The ball starts at the center with a random initial direction each serve.
If the ball touches the net, it is considered a fault and the point is awarded to the opponent.
The AI paddle cannot move beyond the vertical bounds of the canvas.
Score display must show both players' scores side by side.

SuccessCriteria.description: The game runs smoothly at 60 FPS on a mid‑range laptop and a modern smartphone.
All user stories are fully implemented and pass acceptance tests.
Unit tests cover >80% of the core logic (ball movement, collision detection, scoring).
The UI is responsive and works on Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge, iOS Safari, and Android Chrome.
The final product is documented (README, code comments, API reference) and the repository contains a CI pipeline that runs tests on every commit.
